content: The "Three Kids Mine Remediation and Reclamation Act" defines terms like "Federal land" and "Hazardous substance" in relation to the Three Kids Mine Project Site. It also mentions the Henderson Redevelopment Agency in Nevada. The "Three Kids Mine Remediation and Reclamation Act" defines terms related to the project site in Henderson, Nevada, including the Responsible Party and the Secretary of the Interior. It also outlines the map and the State of Nevada's involvement in the redevelopment of the Three Kids Mine Project Site. The Three Kids Mine Project Site encompasses approximately 1,262 acres of Federal and adjacent non-Federal land. The Secretary is required to convey all US interests in the Federal land to the Henderson Redevelopment Agency within 90 days of meeting specified conditions. This includes an appraisal at fair market value. The Henderson Redevelopment Agency will acquire all US interests in the Federal land by paying the fair market value determined through an appraisal conducted according to national standards. The Henderson Redevelopment Agency will acquire US interests in Federal land by paying fair market value determined through an appraisal following national standards. The estimate for assessing, remediating, and reclaiming the Three Kids Mine Project Site will be prepared by the Secretary. The Phase II environmental site assessment for the Three Kids Mine Project Site must be based on a comprehensive report approved by the State and prepared according to ASTM International Standard E-2137-06. The Phase II environmental site assessment for the Three Kids Mine Project Site must adhere to ASTM International Standards E-1527-05 and E-1903-11. The Secretary will review cost information provided by the Henderson Redevelopment Agency, the Responsible Party, and the State to prepare an estimate. If there is a disagreement over the estimate, they will jointly select experts to assist in making the final determination. The Secretary will begin the appraisal and cost estimates within 30 days of enacting the Act. The Henderson Redevelopment Agency or Responsible Party will reimburse appraisal costs. The fair market value of Federal land will be adjusted based on estimates of remediation and reclamation costs. The conveyance under subsection (a) is contingent on the Secretary receiving written agreement from the State. The conveyance under subsection (a) is contingent on the Secretary receiving written notification from the State that a mine remediation and reclamation agreement has been executed, and the Secretary concurring that the requirements have been met. The agreement must be an enforceable consent order between the State and the Responsible Party. The consent order or agreement administered by the State obligates the Responsible Party to perform remediation and reclamation work at the Three Kids Mine Project Site to protect human health and the environment. It includes financial assurance provisions to ensure completion of the remedy. Notification from the agency is required within 90 days of the conveyance. The Henderson Redevelopment Agency must notify the Secretary within 90 days of the conveyance for the Federal land withdrawal for a 10-year period. The public land laws govern location, entry, and patent under mining laws, as well as disposition under mineral leasing and geothermal leasing laws. Any withdrawal under public land laws that includes Federal land no longer needed by the Bureau of Reclamation is relinquished to allow for immediate conveyance. This Act does not interfere with existing Reclamation projects and facilities. SEC. 5. ACEC BOUNDARY ADJUSTMENT. The River Mountains Area of Critical Environmental Concern boundary is adjusted to exclude the Three Kids Mine Project Site. SEC. 6. RESPONSIBILITIES OF THE PARTIES. Parties are responsible for mine remediation and reclamation after conveyance under section 3. After conveyance under section 3, the Responsible Party and the State of Nevada are responsible for complying with the mine remediation and reclamation agreement. If terms of the agreement are not met, the Secretary retains the responsibility to take additional action to protect public health and the environment. The Southern Nevada Public Land Management Act of 1998 does not apply to land conveyed under this Act, unless it affects compliance with environmental or public health laws or the authority of the United States to enforce such laws.
